Award.AwardTitle: NetSE: Medium: Modeling and Analysis of Network Dynamics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
There has been a rapid increase in the number and types of digital networks over the last 2 decades beginning, of course with the Internet, its constituent networks, and the World Wide Web. We now have a wide range of on-line social networks (OSNs) such as Facebook, Twitter, mobile ad hoc networks (MANETs) and delay tolerant networks (DTNs). These networks pervade all aspects of our lives and provide a growing range of services in commerce, business, communications, and connectivity. Many of these networks are continually in a dynamic state of flux and/or extremely large. For example, the topology of a MANET or a DTN is constantly changing, and that of an OSN such as Facebook is rapidly growing and evolving. The modeling, analysis, and measurement of such networks are challenging, due to their dynamism and sizes. As a consequence, traditional mathematical techniques are not suitable and fundamentally new techniques are needed.

This research will focus on three interrelated problems. The first is to develop useful and accurate models that capture the dynamics of today?s social and technological networks. The second is to develop and study a class of techniques for characterizing and searching such networks. These techniques are based on a very simple mechanism, namely to let an agent explore the network by randomly choosing where to go. This is known as a random walk in the mathematics literature and has been shown to exhibit desirable search and characterization properties in static networks that shows promise in dynamic networks. Last, many static networks exhibit what is known as a power law, namely that the distribution for the number of neighbors of a node roughly decays as k−a where k is the number of neighbors and a is a positive constant greater than one. The third problem is to understand what constitutes a power law in a dynamic network, how this power law comes to be, and what implications there might be regarding the health of the network.

Broader Impact. The work will positively impact society by providing a deeper understanding of and a set of tools for managing and monitoring digital networks such as MANETs and OSNs. The project includes a comprehensive dissemination plan including public release of tools for network characterization. The education plan includes cross-specialty seminars, undergraduate involvement in research through a REU site, and international outreach to South America.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Forecasting the growth and death of online social networks & social media cascades: 
Online social networks are a proven success in what the late Nobel laureate Herbert 
Simon called "the marketplace of attention." Our new model assesses the viability of 
websites and social networks in this new attention economy to predict which sites 
are sustainable and which are not. Our efforts have shed a new light into the nature 
of the dynamic processes that create such online social network activity, arguably 
one of the most fundamental open problems in social network analysis. This work 
was published at the 2014 ACM WWW conference. We have also developed ways to 
forecast the popularity of viral social media content. Our approach works by 
extracting statistical information contained in historical (training) data. This is the first 
method that can accurately forecast future social media popularity!  Characterizing large networks via principled network crawling: Characterizing user 
pair and group relationships in online social networks (OSNs) is important for 
applications such as friend recommendation and interest targeting. Due to the large 
scale nature of such networks, it is infeasible to enumerate all pairs and groups, and 
so sampling is used. It is challenging even for OSN service providers to characterize 
pair aqnd group relationships even when they possess complete information about 
their network. It is even more challenging to estimate these statistics in the 
absence of complete information about the network. In a series of papers we 
present methods to perform unbiased samplingan efficient characterization of 
user pair and group motif properties and to identify the k most important nodes 
in an OSN.  In related work we have also developed a new metric and way to 
characterize reciprocity in large networks.  Application of this metric to a variety
of network datasets has exposed a very interesting power law associating 
network size with reciprocity.  Dynamic secrets in hybrid wireless/wireline smart grids. There is increasing interest 
in making our electrical grid smarter so as to be able to use electricity more 
efficiently. This has the benefit of reducing our carbon footprint and, thus, reducing 
global warning. To do this it is necessary to gather information regarding electricity 
usage and to collect it at a central site. This poses a number of serious challenges 
regarding the design and deployment of a communication system to do this, one 
of which has to do with securing the information flows between grid users and grid 
control centers. One of our activities focused on the development and adaptation 
of an approach based on ”dynamic secrets” for use in smart grids where users 
are connected to it through wireless links.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Forecasting the growth and death of online social networks & social media cascades: Online social networks are a proven success in what the late Nobel laureate Herbert Simon called "the marketplace of attention." Our new model assesses the viability of websites and social networks in this new attention economy to predict which sites are sustainable and which are not. Our efforts have shed a new light into the nature of the dynamic processes that create such online social network activity, arguably one of the most fundamental open problems in social network analysis. This work was published at the 2014 ACM WWW conference. We have also developed ways to forecast the popularity of viral social media content. Our approach works by extracting statistical information contained in historical (training) data. This is the first method that can accurately forecast future social media popularity! Characterizing large networks via principled network crawling: Characterizing user pair and group relationships in online social networks (OSNs) is important for applications such as friend recommendation and interest targeting. Due to the large scale nature of such networks, it is infeasible to enumerate all pairs and groups, and so sampling is used. It is challenging even for OSN service providers to characterize pair aqnd group relationships even when they possess complete information about their network. It is even more challenging to estimate these statistics in the absence of complete information about the network. In a series of papers we present methods to perform unbiased samplingan efficient characterization of user pair and group motif properties and to identify the k most important nodes in an OSN. In related work we have also developed a new metric and way to characterize reciprocity in large networks. Application of this metric to a variety of network datasets has exposed a very interesting power law associating network size with reciprocity. Dynamic secrets in hybrid wireless/wireline smart grids. There is increasing interest in making our electrical grid smarter so as to be able to use electricity more efficiently. This has the benefit of reducing our carbon footprint and, thus, reducing global warning. To do this it is necessary to gather information regarding electricity usage and to collect it at a central site. This poses a number of serious challenges regarding the design and deployment of a communication system to do this, one of which has to do with securing the information flows between grid users and grid control centers. One of our activities focused on the development and adaptation of an approach based on "dynamic secrets" for use in smart grids where users are connected to it through wireless links.
